Furthermore, Mahamati!

Mahamati!
What are the characteristics of the essence of the three dharmas?

Mahamati!
What are the characteristics of the essence of the dharmas of causes and conditions?

This is called the method of observing the characteristics of the five dharmas, the realm of the inner realization and practice of all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. You and all Bodhisattvas should study in this way.
Furthermore, Great Wisdom!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should thoroughly contemplate the characteristics of the two kinds of no-self.
Great Wisdom!
What are the two kinds?
First, the cognition of the no-self of persons;
Second, the cognition of the no-self of dharmas.
What is the cognition of the no-self of persons?
It means being apart from the aggregates, realms, and sense bases that are mine and mine's;
Because cognition, karma, and craving do not arise;
Because of falsely grasping and clinging to the eyes, forms, and so forth;
Because all faculties, bodies, and houses are seen in one's own mind;ğŸ”½Because of conceptualization;
Because of the conceptualization of consciousness;
Like a flowing river, seeds, a burning lamp, wind and clouds, moment by moment changing, restless and agitated, like a monkey or a fly, delighting in impure objects;
Insatiable like a fire;
Because of being perfumed by the objects of conceptualization since beginningless time;
Like a waterwheel, a cart, or a machine, in the three realms one gives rise to various forms and various bodies, like an illusion or a reanimated corpse.
Great Wisdom!
Observing the characteristics of phenomena in this way with skillful means and wisdom is called the knowledge of the realm of the characteristics of the wisdom of the non-self of persons.
Great Wisdom!
What is the wisdom of the non-self of phenomena?
It means to truly discriminate the characteristics of the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
Great Wisdom!

Bodhisattvas observe that the aggregates, realms, and sense-fields are devoid of self and what belongs to self. The aggregates, realms, and sense-fields are mutually bound by the ropes of karma and craving. Because they arise from causes and conditions, they are devoid of self and devoid of an agent.
Great Wisdom!

The aggregates, realms, and sense-fields are devoid of the same characteristics and different characteristics. Therefore, they are named based on unreal characteristics. It is because foolish ordinary beings falsely discriminate and take them to be existent, not because those who realize reality see them as existent.
Great Wisdom!

Bodhisattvas observe the mind, thought, and consciousness in this way. Because all the five dharmas are devoid of characteristics, the causes and conditions are nonexistent. This is called the characteristic of the realm of the wisdom of the non-self of all dharmas.
Great Wisdom!
Bodhisattvas, having well understood the non-self of all dharmas, observe suchness and cultivate tranquil practices. They will soon attain the first ground of joy.
Having well observed the ground of joy, the various grounds will gradually become clearer, up to attaining the Dharma cloud ground.

The bodhisattvas dwelling in that Dharma Cloud Ground, on a great lotus king's seat adorned with innumerable jewels, in a great jeweled palace born from the realm of the illusions of true karma, sit upon it surrounded by reverent fellow practitioners, and the buddhas of the ten directions extend their hands to confer the crown empowerment, bestowing the rank of buddhahood, like a wheel-turning king bestowing the crown empowerment on the prince, surpassing the stage of the Buddha's disciples.
Having surpassed the stage of the Buddha's disciples, they contemplate the buddhas' teachings and practice them as they are, attaining mastery over all dharmas.
Having attained mastery, they are called those who have attained the TathÄgata's unsurpassed Dharma body, because they see the non-self of dharmas.
Great Wisdom!
This is called the characteristic of the non-self of dharmas as they really are.
Great Wisdom!
You and all bodhisattvas should study in this way.

World-Honored One!
If I and the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas hear it, we will be able to avoid the wrong views of existence and nonexistence, and quickly attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.

At that time the World-Honored One, regarding the meaning of this verse, further explained it to the holy MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« Bodhisattva, saying:
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
There are four kinds of characteristics of establishment and slander.
What are the four?
First, establishing the characteristic of non-existence;
Second, establishing the characteristic of non-correct view;
Third, establishing the characteristic of non-existent cause;
Fourth, establishing the characteristics of non-existent entities.
MaheÅ›vara!
These are called the four kinds of establishment.
MaheÅ›vara!
What are the characteristics of slander?
MaheÅ›vara!
Observing the established dharmas of wrong views, not seeing the true characteristics, one slanders all dharmas, saying they are all non-existent.
MaheÅ›vara!
This is called the characteristic of establishing slander.
Furthermore, MaheÅ›vara!
What is the characteristic of establishing non-existence?
It refers to discriminating that the aggregates, realms, and sense bases are non-existent dharmas, because they are the conceptual proliferation of beginningless time and do not truly exist;
Yet one clings to the same characteristics and different characteristics, thinking that these dharmas are thus and thus, ultimately not different.
MaheÅ›vara!
This arises from clinging to the perfuming of afflictions that have come from immeasurable lifetimes.
MaheÅ›vara!
This is called the characteristic of establishing non-existence.
MaheÅ›vara!
What is the characteristic of establishing non-right views?
MaheÅ›vara!
Within those aggregates, realms, and sense bases, there is no self, person, sentient being, or life-force, yet one establishes wrong views, saying there is a self and so forth.
MaheÅ›vara!
This is called the characteristic of establishing wrong views.
MaheÅ›vara!
What is the characteristic of establishing non-existent causes?

It means the initial consciousness does not arise from causes, it is originally unborn and later arises like an illusion, originally there are no caused things, but because of the eye, form, light, and thought, consciousness arises, and after arising it returns to cessation.
MaheÅ›vara!
This is called the characteristic of establishing non-existent causes.
MaheÅ›vara!
What is the characteristic of slandering the Dharma by establishing non-existent entities?
It means establishing and clinging to the non-existence of things such as space, cessation, nirvÄá¹‡a, non-action, and so forth.

MaheÅ›vara!
All dharmas are like the horns of rabbits, horses, donkeys, and camels, and hair-nets, and so forth, because they are apart from the characteristics of establishing existence and non-existence.
MaheÅ›vara!
The characteristic of slandering that is established is because ordinary beings falsely discriminate;
Not knowing that it is only the mind that sees, all dharmas exist, but are not seen by the sages.
Mahamati!
This is called the characteristic of slandering the Dharma that establishes what does not exist.
Mahamati!
You should distance yourself from the characteristic of slandering the Dharma that establishes wrong views.
Furthermore, Mahamati!

The bodhisattva-mahasattvas truly know the mind, thought, consciousness, the essence of the five dharmas, and the two kinds of no-self, and manifest various kinds of forms in order to bring peace to sentient beings, like those false [appearances] that have nothing to discriminate, and exist due to the Dharma of causes and conditions.

The bodhisattva-mahasattvas are also like this, relying on sentient beings to manifest various forms like a wish-fulfilling jewel, according to the thoughts of all sentient beings, manifesting in the great assembly in the buddha lands like an illusion, like a dream, like an echo, like the moon in the water, like a reflection in a mirror;

The Buddha told MahÄmati:
MahÄmati!
Emptiness is a phrase that refers to the essence of deluded phenomena.
MahÄmati!
Based on the essence of deluded phenomena that are clung to and grasped, emptiness, non-arising, non-essence, and non-duality are spoken of.

What are the seven?
First, the emptiness of characteristics;
Second, the emptiness of the existence and non-existence of all dharmas;
Third, the emptiness of practice;
Fourth, the emptiness of non-practice;
Fifth, the emptiness of the inexpressibility of all dharmas;
Sixth, the great emptiness of the ultimate truth and holy wisdom;

This is called the emptiness of the inexpressibility of all dharmas.
Great Wisdom!

This is called the great emptiness of the ultimate truth of the holy wisdom.

Future and present bodhisattvas should not cling to the characteristic of self.

At that time the holy Mahamati Bodhisattva, observing all sentient beings in the future, again requested the Buddha, saying:

The Buddha told the holy Mahamati Bodhisattva-mahasattva:
Mahamati!

What are the four?
First, skillfully knowing the appearances seen by one's own mind;
Second, because they are far removed from arising, abiding, and ceasing;
Third, because they skillfully understand the existence and non-existence of external phenomena;
Fourth, because they delight in cultivating the wisdom of inner realization.

Bodhisattvas who accomplish these four dharmas will attain great accomplishment and become true practitioners.
Mahamati!

Bodhisattva-mahasattvas observe that the three realms are only created by the one mind;
Because they are devoid of self and what belongs to self;
Because they are devoid of movement and awareness;
Because they are free from grasping and abandoning;
Because of the mind that is perfumed by the three realms and gives rise to conceptual proliferation from beginningless time due to false attachment;
Because they are constantly bound by various forms and actions;
Because the six destinies falsely appear within the body, resources, and the world.
Mahamati!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahasattvas' skillful knowledge of the characteristics of the appearances of their own minds.
Mahamati!
How do all bodhisattva-mahasattvas see the dharma of being far removed from arising, abiding, and ceasing?
It means observing all dharmas as illusory and dream-like.
All dharmas are not produced due to the absence of self and other, because they are known and seen in accordance with one's own mind;
Because there are no external dharmas;
The various consciousnesses do not arise, observing that the causes and conditions have no accumulation;
Seeing that the causes and conditions of the three realms exist;
Not seeing the internal and external dharmas as having real substance;
Far removed from the incorrect views that produce dharmas;
Entering into the illusory characteristics of all dharmas.

At that time, the bodhisattva is said to have attained the first ground and the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, because he is far removed from the mind, thought, and the characteristics of the five dharmas;

This is called the bodhisattva's good understanding of the existence and non-existence of external dharmas, and thus accomplishing the great one who practices in accordance with reality.

You should cultivate and study in this way.
At that time, the holy Mahamati Bodhisattva again requested the Buddha, saying:

I and all bodhisattvas, well understanding the characteristics of the causes and conditions of dharmas, will be free from the errors of non-existence, existence, and incorrect views, as well as conceptual thoughts and discriminations of dharmas arising sequentially or simultaneously.
The Buddha told Mahamati Bodhisattva, saying:
Mahamati!
All dharmas have two kinds of characteristics of the accumulation of causes and conditions, namely internal and external.
Mahamati!

As for the characteristics of the collection of external causes and conditions, it refers to things like a lump of clay. Due to the conditions of a stick, a wheel, a rope, human effort, and skillful means, a pot is produced.
Great Wisdom!

Just as a pot is produced from causes and conditions such as a lump of clay, so too are cloth from thread, a mat from grass, a sprout from a seed, and so forth. Human effort produces curd, and from curd, butter is obtained, and from butter, ghee.

This is called the characteristics of the collection of external causes and conditions, which should be understood from the lower to the higher.
Great Wisdom!
What are the characteristics of the collection of internal causes and conditions?
Great Wisdom!
Ignorance, karma, and craving, and so forth, are called the characteristics of the collection of internal causes and conditions.
Great Wisdom!

Due to ignorance and so forth, the aggregates, realms, and sense bases are produced, and this is called the characteristics of the collection of causes and conditions. However, ordinary beings falsely discriminate and each sees separate characteristics.

The continuous cause is able to grasp internal and external dharmas, the seeds of the aggregates, and so forth.

The characteristic cause is able to produce the continuity of successive activities without interruption.

The productive cause is able to act as the dominant condition, like a wheel-turning king.
MaheÅ›vara!
The revealing cause is able to manifest the arising of deluded phenomena, like a lamp illuminating forms and so forth.
MaheÅ›vara!
The mutually dependent cause is, when ceasing, not seen to give rise to deluded phenomena, because the continuity of events is severed.
MaheÅ›vara!
Such dharmas are the deluded discriminations of the minds of ordinary beings.
MaheÅ›vara!
These dharmas do not arise sequentially, nor do they arise simultaneously.
Why is this?
Great Wisdom!
If all dharmas were born simultaneously, cause and effect could not be distinguished, because cause and effect and the characteristics of the body are not seen.
